docs.abstract: Alvin Ailey Amer Dance Theater, on its 1st tour of Latin Amer in 15 yrs, has been exuberantly recd by audiences in Brazil; initial backstage friction, however, had Ailey threaten to cancel his opening night at Rio's munic theater; Ailey wound up 2-wk stay with performances in Sao Paulo, after encountering series of problems with conservative adm of Rio theater; describes problems (M)

docs.snippet: LA PAZ, Bolivia--The first elections permitted by Bolivia's armed forces in 12 years illustrate the difficulty of shifting from military dictatorship to even the most limited kind of democracy in South America's authoritarian regimes.

docs.abstract: Article on election focuses on difficulty of shifting from mil dictatorship to limited kind of democracy; illus (M)

headline.main: Generals' Elections Can Get Out of Hand

docs.snippet: QUITO, Ecuador, July 15--The plans of the military to withdraw from power after six years of rule here enter a critical phase tomorrow as Ecuadoreans vote in their first presidential election in 10 years.
docs.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador, July 15--The plans of the military to withdraw from power after six years of rule here enter a critical phase tomorrow as Ecuadoreans vote in their first presidential election in 10 years.
docs.abstract: 1st Pres election in 10 yrs set; combined with vote for mayors and prov officials; Sixto Duran Ballen deemed front-runner for Pres; backed by center-right coalition called Natl Constitutionalist Front; other candidates are Raul Clemente Huerta (Liberal Party), Rodrigo Borja (Dem Left), Rene Mauge (Communist Party), Jaime Roldos (Coalition of Popular Forces) and Oberdon Calderon; Govt denies rumors of coup that developed because of arrival in Quito of battalion of tanks (M)

headline.main: ECUADOREANS VOTING FOR PRESIDENT TODAY; First Such Election in a Decade Is Aimed at Bringing an End to 6 Years of Military Rule New Constitution Approved Battalion of Tanks Arrive Military Coup in 1972

byline.original: By DAVID VIDAL Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 19-- Paraguay's chief of military intelligence has given United States investigators sworn evidence, including a copy of a coded message, linking Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, the former chief of Chile's secret police, to...
docs.lead_paragraph: ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 19-- Paraguay's chief of military intelligence has given United States investigators sworn evidence, including a copy of a coded message, linking Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, the former chief of Chile's secret police, to the assassination of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, in Washington.
docs.abstract: Col Benito Guanes, Paraguay's chief of mil intelligence, gives US investigators sworn evidence, including copy of coded message, linking Gen Manuel Contreras Sepulveda to Letelier murder; Guanes says he received telephone call from Contreras in '76, followed by coded telegram signed by Contreras, asking that Paraguayan passports be issued to Chilean agents Michael Vernon Townley and Capt Armando Fernandez Larios (M)

headline.main: Paraguayan Links Chilean General to Letelier Case

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The 25th anniversary of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, now the third long  est reigning queen in British history, has been marked by Great Britain with a set  of four special commemoratives. The issues depict symbols of royalty associated with...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 25th anniversary of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, now the third long est reigning queen in British history, has been marked by Great Britain with a set of four special commemoratives. The issues depict symbols of royalty associated with the pomp and circumstance that no one in the world does better than the British.
docs.abstract: Comment on Canada preparing to issue stamps marking games, which will be held in Edmonton (S)

headline.main: STAMPS; Coronation Anniversary Canada World Cup
